prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario (the author) is in the wrong when they want their girlfriend to start contributing to the bills after a single incident.

First, the author and their girlfriend live together. He pays all the rent and bills, and she works part-time. The situation that triggered this is when he forgot his wallet and asked her to pay for takeout, which she resented. He's now considering making her pay some bills as a result.

Hmm, so the key points are: He's been covering everything, she's part-time, and the incident was a small amount. The author is upset not just about the incident but about her attitude. He feels she should start contributing for principle. The question is whether he's in the wrong.

From a relationship perspective, fairness is important. If they're in a committed relationship, splitting expenses might be expected, especially if they're living together. However, she works part-time, which might mean she has limited income. The author mentions that she might not be able to pay a lot, so maybe he's expecting a small contribution. But is making her start paying because of one incident fair?

The incident itself was a $40 takeout. The author might feel that since he pays everything, she should have no problem contributing even a small amount. However, the girlfriend's reaction was negative, which could indicate she feels taken advantage of or that the responsibility isn't shared. The author's frustration is about principle—maybe he feels she's not pulling her weight, even if it's a small amount.

But is it fair to make her pay more just because of one incident where she was upset? The author is generalizing from a single event. Maybe her reaction was due to feeling that she's always expected to cover things without any input. Communication is key here. Instead of punishing her, discussing expectations might be better.

Also, the author hasn't mentioned talking to her about splitting expenses before. If he suddenly starts making her pay without discussing it, that could be seen as unfair. Relationships require mutual agreement on financial responsibilities. The author might be in the wrong if he's unilaterally changing the arrangement without considering her perspective or discussing it openly.

On the other hand, if the author feels that contributing to shared expenses is fair, especially in a living situation, then expecting some contribution could be reasonable. However, the way he's approaching it—holding a single incident against her—might not be fair. The root issue is about shared responsibility and communication.

So, the author might be in the wrong if he's being rigid and not considering her financial situation, or if he's not having an open conversation. The fact that he's focusing on a single incident and using it as a catalyst for bigger changes without discussing could be problematic. The answer might be A (Yes, he's in the wrong) because of the lack of communication and overreaction to a minor incident.
